Hydrochlorothiazide does not delay the progression of renal disease in patients with type 2 diabetes. In contrast, SGLT2 inhibitors, finerenone, and angiotensin receptor blockers are all known to provide renal protection and slow the progression of diabetic kidney disease.

questions.text: True regarding Oral Cholera vaccine ‘Sanchol’ is: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Bivalent with 2 doses

 

The oral cholera vaccine ‘Sanchol’ is a bivalent vaccine designed to protect against serotypes O1 and O139 of the cholera bacteria. It is administered as 2 liquid doses for individuals aged 1 year and older, with a booster dose recommended every 2 years. The vaccine does not contain subunit B antitoxin; hence it does not require a buffer during administration.

 

Educational Objective:


CHOLERA ORAL VACCINES:

 

  •  Dukoral (WC-rBS): Monovalent, V cholera O1 plus Recombinant Toxin B subunit.
    • 2 doses (if age ≥6 years) and booster once/ 2 years
    • 3 doses (if age b/w 2-5 years) and booster dose once per 6 months.
  •  Sanchol and mORCVAX: Bivalent, Serogroups O1 & O139, No toxin B subunit, No buffer required. 2 liquid doses after the age of 1 year and booster after 2 years.
  • Euvichol: it is just like Sanchol. Bivalent with 2 doses.

questions.text: Identify the part of the cochlear implant marked? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Grounding electrode

 

 

The marked part in the image is the grounding electrode, also known as the reference electrode. In a cochlear implant, the grounding electrode is usually implanted in the temporalis area. Its primary function is to serve as a reference point for electrical signals, ensuring accurate signal transmission and reducing noise interference during the processing of sound signals.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amplifier: An amplifier is not a distinct part of the cochlear implant. Instead, the sound processor amplifies and processes the sound signals before transmitting them to the receiver.

 

Option C. Receiver: The receiver in a cochlear implant is a component that lies under the skin and receives sound signals from the external transmitter. It is not the marked part in the image.

 

Option D. Electrode array: The electrode array is implanted inside the cochlea and is responsible for stimulating the auditory nerve. It directly interacts with the cochlea, unlike the grounding electrode that is positioned externally or at a different implant site.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The grounding electrode or reference electrode in a cochlear implant is implanted in the temporalis area and is crucial for accurate signal transmission by providing a reference point for electrical signals.

questions.text: Fatty liver is caused by the accumulation of which substance? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A. Triglycerides

 

Explanation: 

 

Fatty liver (steatosis) is characterized by the abnormal accumulation of triglycerides within parenchymal cells, particularly in the liver. This occurs due to a disruption in normal lipid metabolism where the rate of triglyceride acquisition exceeds the rate of triglyceride removal. This accumulation can result from excessive intake of fats, defective transport mechanisms, or metabolic disorders affecting fat processing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein) - While LDL carries cholesterol to tissues, it is not the primary substance that accumulates in fatty liver. LDL abnormalities are more commonly associated with atherosclerosis rather than hepatic steatosis.

 

Option C. Lipoprotein - This is a general class of biochemical compounds that facilitate lipid transport in the bloodstream. While lipoproteins are involved in fat metabolism, the specific accumulation in fatty liver is of triglycerides, not lipoproteins themselves.

 

Option D. VLDL (Very Low-Density Lipoprotein) - Although impaired VLDL secretion can contribute to fatty liver by preventing triglyceride export from hepatocytes, the substance that actually accumulates is triglycerides, not VLDL itself.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Fatty liver (steatosis) results from the accumulation of triglycerides within hepatocytes, which may occur due to excessive intake, impaired export, or defective metabolism of fats.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract. The patient's parents report that he has had multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis. Dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test results show an abnormal pattern. What is the primary suspicion based on these findings? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chronic granulomatous disease

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract, along with a history of multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis in a young child, strongly suggests a primary immunodeficiency disorder. The abnormal dihydrorhodamine (DHR) test result further supports the diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease (CGD).

 

CGD is a rare inherited disorder characterized by defective oxygen-dependent killing of microorganisms by phagocytic cells, such as neutrophils and macrophages. This defect is caused by mutations in the genes encoding components of the NADPH oxidase enzyme complex, which is responsible for generating reactive oxygen species (ROS) necessary for microbial killing. The inability to produce sufficient ROS leads to recurrent infections, especially with catalase-positive organisms.

 

The DHR test is a flow cytometry-based assay that measures the production of ROS by neutrophils after stimulation. An abnormal DHR test result, as seen in this patient, is consistent with the diagnosis of CGD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID) is a group of disorders characterized by defects in both cellular and humoral immunity.

 

X-linked SCID is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder characterized by chronic diarrhea, periodic respiratory infection, and acquired maternal T cell-mediated GVHD. Mutations in interleukin-2 receptor gamma (IL2RG) can result in X-SCID. While patients with SCID are also susceptible to recurrent infections, the presentation typically involves opportunistic infections and failure to thrive, which are not mentioned in this case.

 

Option C. Sialyl Lewis X defect, also known as leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 2 (LAD-2), is a rare disorder characterized by defective leukocyte rolling and adhesion due to a deficiency in the sialyl Lewis X ligand. While patients with LAD-2 may present with recurrent infections, the DHR test would not be abnormal in this condition.

 

Option D. Integrin defects, such as leukocyte adhesion deficiency type 1 (LAD-1), are characterized by defective leukocyte adhesion and migration due to mutations in the genes encoding integrins. Although patients with LAD-1 may present with recurrent infections, the DHR test would not be abnormal in this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic granulomatous disease should be suspected in a child presenting with recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, particularly involving the skin and respiratory tract, along with a history of multiple abscesses and lymphadenitis, and an abnormal DHR test result.

questions.text: Which of the following is a characteristic infection associated with Nocardia Asteroides? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Brain abscess

 

Explanation:

 

Brain abscess is a characteristic infection associated with Nocardia asteroides. In cases of disseminated nocardiosis, the brain is the most common site of extrapulmonary infection. Nocardia species, including N. asteroides, initially cause pulmonary infection in most cases, but then can spread hematogenously to distant sites. When this dissemination occurs, brain abscess formation is the most frequently observed extrapulmonary manifestation. These brain abscesses are often multiple, have a high mortality rate, and are particularly common in immunocompromised patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diarrhea - This is incorrect because Nocardia species typically cause respiratory tract infections, subcutaneous infections, or disseminated disease, but are not characteristically associated with gastrointestinal manifestations like diarrhea. Nocardia primarily affects the lungs, brain, and skin rather than the digestive tract.

 

Option B. Secondary dissemination to the liver - While Nocardia can disseminate to various organs from primary pulmonary infection, liver involvement is not specifically identified as a characteristic or common site of Nocardia infection. The brain, skin, kidneys, bone, and muscle are more typical sites of dissemination.

 

Option D. Colonic diverticulosis - This is incorrect because colonic diverticulosis is not an infectious condition caused by Nocardia or any other microorganism. Diverticulosis refers to the presence of diverticula (small pouches) in the colon wall, which is typically related to age, diet, and genetic factors rather than infection.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Nocardia asteroides characteristically causes pulmonary infections that can disseminate hematogenously, with brain abscess being the most common manifestation of extrapulmonary nocardiosis, especially in immunocompromised hosts.

choices.text: Primary active transport
Facilitated diffusion
Simple diffusion
Secondary active transport

questions.text: Which of the following process is responsible for glucose absorption into the intestine?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Secondary active transport

 

Explanation   

 

Glucose is absorbed into the intestine by secondary active transport because this process allows for the efficient uptake of glucose against its concentration gradient.

 

Secondary active transport involves the coupled movement of two substances across a membrane, where the movement of one substance is dependent on the electrochemical gradient created by the movement of another substance. In the case of glucose absorption in the intestine, the secondary active transport mechanism relies on the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium pump.

 

The process of glucose absorption in the intestine occurs in the brush border membrane of the intestinal epithelial cells, specifically in the small intestine. Here's a step-by-step explanation of how secondary active transport facilitates glucose absorption:

 

  1. Sodium-Potassium Pump: The sodium-potassium pump actively transports sodium ions (Na+) out of the epithelial cells and into the intercellular space, using ATP energy. This creates a concentration gradient where the sodium concentration is higher outside the cell.
  2. Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter: The sodium gradient generated by the sodium-potassium pump is utilized by a specific protein called the sodium-glucose cotransporter (SGLT). This cotransporter binds both sodium ions and glucose molecules on the outer surface of the cell.
  3. Co-transport of Sodium and Glucose: As sodium ions bind to the SGLT protein, their movement into the cell down the concentration gradient provides the necessary energy for the simultaneous movement of glucose against its concentration gradient. Glucose is "dragged" along with the sodium ions as they enter the cell.
  4. Glucose Transporter: Once inside the epithelial cell, glucose is transported across the basolateral membrane (the inner surface of the cell) and into the bloodstream by facilitated diffusion through a specific glucose transporter called GLUT2.

 

Overall, the energy stored in the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium pump is used to actively transport both sodium and glucose into the intestinal epithelial cells. This secondary active transport mechanism allows for the absorption of glucose from the intestinal lumen into the bloodstream efficiently, even when the concentration of glucose is higher inside the cell than in the lumen.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary active transport: Incorrect because primary active transport involves the direct use of ATP to move substances against their gradient, which does not apply to glucose absorption in this context.

 

Option B. Facilitated diffusion: Incorrect as this method does not involve the active transport of glucose against its concentration gradient; it only allows movement along the gradient.

 

Option C. Simple diffusion: Incorrect because simple diffusion does not involve any transport proteins and occurs only along the concentration gradient, which is not sufficient for glucose absorption in the intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucose absorption in the intestine occurs via secondary active transport, utilizing the energy from the sodium gradient created by the sodium-potassium ATPase to transport glucose against its concentration gradient. This process is crucial for efficient glucose uptake from the intestinal lumen into the bloodstream.

questions.text: Which muscle is attached to the marked bony structure? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Iliopsoas

 

Explanation:

 

The radiograph shows a lateral view of the pelvis and proximal femur. The marked bony structure is the lesser trochanter of the femur. The iliopsoas muscle, consisting of the iliacus and psoas major muscles, attaches to the lesser trochanter.

 

The iliopsoas crosses the hip joint anteriorly, causing flexion. The iliacus originates from the iliac fossa, while the psoas major originates from the lumbar vertebrae. These two muscles fuse together and insert near the lesser trochanter of the femur, forming the floor of the femoral triangle.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gluteus maximus : The gluteus maximus muscle inserts on the gluteal tuberosity of the femur, not the lesser trochanter.

 

Option C. Gluteus medius : The gluteus medius muscle inserts on the greater trochanter of the femur, not the lesser trochanter.

 

Option D. Sartorius : The sartorius muscle forms the lateral boundary of the femoral triangle but does not attach directly to the lesser trochanter. It inserts on the medial surface of the proximal tibia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The iliopsoas muscle, consisting of the iliacus and psoas major, inserts on the lesser trochanter of the femur. It is an important hip flexor muscle.

 

Femoral Triangle:
